An experimental paradigm for the assessment of realistic human multitasking
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 19 March 2018

An experimental paradigm for the assessment of realistic human multitasking

  • Otmar Bock  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0485-67651,
  • Uwe Drescher1,
  • Christin Janouch2,
  • Mathias Haeger1,
  • Wim van Winsum3 &
  • Claudia Voelcker-Rehage2 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages61–70(2019)Cite this article

  • 360 Accesses

  • 1 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Human multitasking has been evaluated with paradigms that administered two—rarely three—concurrent tasks. In everyday life, however, we usually face an ever-changing sequence of distinct concurrent tasks. Available studies therefore provided valuable insights into our ability for dual tasking, but they did not address the natural interplay of dual tasking and task switching. The present study was undertaken to explore the feasibility of two new paradigms which replicate that interplay in virtual reality. We used car driving simulator software to implement a virtual car-driving task as well as a virtual street-crossing task. Either task was administered alone, as well as concurrently with a battery of loading tasks that mimicked activities of everyday life. The loading tasks used different sensory modalities, different cognitive processes, and different output channels and were presented in an ever-changing sequence. Cronbach’s alpha scores of key registered variables were high, which indicates that our approach is reliable. Driving and street-crossing performance deteriorated under multitask conditions, which indicates that our approach is sensitive to multitasking. This is the first study to demonstrate the feasibility of an experimental paradigm for the assessment of natural multitasking, i.e., of combined dual tasking and task switching. This paradigm could be of interest for basic science as well as for prevention and rehabilitation settings.

Introduction

Technological progress challenges our ability to cope with multiple tasks at the same time. Often-cited examples are car driving and street crossing: In both situations, we need to control the speed and direction of our movement, watch for and obey road signs, detect and avoid obstacles, anticipate imminent collisions with other pedestrians or vehicles and act accordingly, navigate toward the desired destination of our trip, and plan alternative routes if traffic situation so requires.

A large number of studies documented that multitasking is associated with performance decrements. Jersild (1927) was the first to notice that humans slow down when they perform two tasks alternately rather than either task repeatedly. This slowing, later called ‘switching costs,’ has been attributed to two distinct phenomena: adjustment to a new task and suppression of adjustment to the previous task (Rogers and Monsell 1995). In another line of research, Telford (1931) administered two tasks in close succession and observed that the first task was processed with a normal reaction time but the second with a prolonged reaction time. This prolongation, later called ‘dual-task costs,’ was attributed to the existence of a central processing bottleneck which can deal with only one task at a time (Welford 1952). According to an alternative interpretation, both tasks compete for a central processing resource and if resource demand exceeds resource availability, performance suffers (Kahnemann 1973). Later work has shown that dual-task costs are lower when the two tasks are dissimilar, for example, when one uses visual and the other auditory inputs; the notion of a central processing resource has therefore been modified by stipulating separate resources for different processing needs (Wickens 1991). It has further been argued that multitasking is coordinated by a supervisory attention system, which assigns task priorities, schedules task processing, allocates resources, monitors progress, and inhibits undesired processing (Burgess 2000). The concept of a supervisory attention system is highly similar to that of executive functions; both are thought to reside in the prefrontal cortex (Dux et al. 2009; Norman and Shallice 1986).

The ability to multitask can be compromised by neurological disease (Burgess et al. 2000), psychiatric disorders (Laloyaux et al. 2014), and old age (Verhaeghen et al. 2003). A number of studies explored possible remedies and documented that switching costs (Kray and Lindenberger 2000; Strobach et al. 2012) and dual-task costs (McDowd 1986; Schumacher et al. 2001) can indeed be reduced through extended practice. Importantly, the benefits of practice often transferred to new dual tasks (Hazeltine et al. 2002; Liepelt et al. 2011; Minear and Shah 2008; Zinke et al. 2012). The latter finding raises hope that practice of specific dual tasks, administered in rehabilitation settings or by computer programs at home, may ameliorate the affected persons’ deficits in everyday life.

It is important to note that our knowledge about multitasking comes largely from standardized laboratory paradigms, which differ from typical multitasking situations in everyday life. To give some representative examples, participants in one task-switching study (Monsell et al. 2003) saw a sequence of digits and were asked to classify digits either by parity or by value. On trial A, they had to depress one of two buttons depending on whether the displayed digit was even or odd; on trial B, they had to depress them depending on whether the displayed digit was larger or smaller than 5; trials alternated according to ABABAB… Participants in another task-switching study (Mayr and Keele 2000) had to depress one of four buttons to indicate which of four rectangular objects deviated from the other three objects with respect to its color (trial A: black/white), orientation (trial B: vertical/oblique), or movement (trial C: still/small-amplitude movement); trials were again presented in an alternating sequence. In one dual-task study (Ewolds et al. 2017), participants used a handheld joystick to track a moving dot with a cursor, and they concurrently depressed a pedal when hearing a high- rather than a low-pitched tone. In another dual-task study (Manor et al. 2016), participants walked down a hallway and concurrently checked boxes.

These paradigms share several characteristics which are common in laboratory research but are rarely found in daily life. Laboratory paradigms typically

  • administer a limited set of well-defined stimuli and therefore disregard the incessant barrage of relevant and irrelevant stimuli in real life. It is well established that distraction by irrelevant stimuli has a profound effect on performance (Sekuler et al. 2000; Feng et al. 2017),

  • call for a limited set of well-defined responses and therefore neglect the rich repertoire of possible motor actions in real life. It is known that task performance depends critically on the number of possible actions (Hick 1952; Proctor and Schneider 2017),

  • involve tasks with no appreciable relevance for everyday life and therefore disregard the role of motivation and purpose in everyday behavior. It has been shown that performance depends on whether a task is desirable and meaningful (Kleinsorge 2001; Mayer 1976),

  • present only two—rarely three—tasks repetitively and therefore do not replicate the ever-changing sequences which are typical of real life. Research suggests that variability and uncertainty strongly influence task performance (Shea and Morgan 1979; Koch 2005).

Given these differences between common laboratory paradigms and typical situations of real life, it is not surprising that motor (Bock and Beurskens 2010; Bock and Züll 2013) as well as cognitive performance (Verhaeghen et al. 2012) differs considerably between laboratory and everyday life. In other words, the ecological validity (Chaytor and Schmitter-Edgecombe 2003) of most laboratory research may be limited. This limitation could well include laboratory research about the principles, deficits, and trainability of multitasking (Wollesen and Voelcker-Rehage 2014).

According to the above considerations, we posit that the ecological validity of multitasking research would benefit from the use of experimental paradigms that involve many rather than a few stimuli, many rather than a few responses, meaningful rather than meaningless tasks, and an ever-changing rather than a repetitive task sequence. The purpose of the present study was to exemplify our view of ecologically valid multitasking by presenting two prototypes—two rather than one to underline generalizability—and to document that such paradigms can be sensitive to the costs of multitasking. Sensitivity of the proposed paradigms is not self-evident; one could argue that everyday activities are familiar and automatized such that they can be processed alternately or concurrently without appreciable costs (Schumacher et al. 2001). One could also argue that processing of more than 2–3 alternating or concurrent activities is so complicated that performance will break down altogether (Helm 1981). In other words, the proposed paradigms may be unsuitable for experimental research because of floor or ceiling effects.

Several recent multitasking studies introduced experimental paradigms which simulate common scenarios of everyday life such as car driving, street crossing, and grocery shopping. Those paradigms were implemented in virtual reality to provide a realistic, immersive, and interactive environment without the inconveniences, safety hazards, and lack of experimental control that are characteristic of real life. Stimuli were complex and ever changing, tasks were purposeful, and required responses were embedded in complex and ongoing behavior. Unfortunately, however, those paradigms still compared participants’ performance with and without a single concurrent task in separate blocks. For example, one study compared simulated car driving with and without concurrent mobile texting (Drews et al. 2009), and another study compared simulated street crossing with and without concurrent mobile Internet use (Byington and Schwebel 2013). The few studies which administered more than one concurrent task did so in separate blocks. For example, car driving was combined with pattern detection in one block and with color memory in another block (Cassavaugh and Kramer 2009), and street crossing was combined with music listening in one block and with cell phone conversation in another block (Neider et al. 2011). Compared to these virtual reality approaches to multitasking, the main advance of the present approach is to replace a repetitive task sequence by an ever-changing task sequence. This is a critical difference: Persons who dual-task with loading task A in one experimental block, with loading task B in another, and with loading task C in yet another block will incur dual-task costs only, while those who dual-task with a mixed sequence of A, B, and C in the same block will incur dual-task costs as well as switching costs. To our knowledge, ours is the first study to introduce such a natural interplay of task switching and dual tasking.

Methods

Sample

For a controlled feasibility trial, six young adults participated in the driving task (age 24–30 years, M = 26.5, SD = 2.1, three females) and ten in the street-crossing task. One-half of the latter group (age 20–23, M = 21.2, SD = 1.3, 5 females) crossed streets on which cars drove at constant inter-vehicle distances, and the other half (age 20–27, M = 23.2, SD = 3.1, 5 males) crossed streets with variable inter-vehicle distances. Participants were recruited via notices posted at public places and at the Internet sites of the German Sport University and the Chemnitz University of Technology. All participants were unexperienced in multitasking research and all were healthy by self-report. The study was approved by the Ethics Commission of the German Sport University, and all participants signed an informed consent statement.

Tasks

Car-driving scenario

Participants sat in front of three 46” TV screens which offered a horizontal field of view of 195° in total. They used a steering wheel and pedals to control the display of a softly winding country road, rendered by a commercially available driving simulator (Carnetsoft®). The landscape was populated by trees, bushes, hay-rolls, animals, buildings, road signs, and by vehicles which travelled in both lanes at a constant speed of 70 km/h (see Fig. 1a), but there were no road intersections and no traffic lights. Participants drove a car modeled as VW Golf with automatic transmission. They followed a car which, at irregular intervals, approached a construction zone where it slowed down to 40 km/h within 7 s, kept that speed for 6 s, and then sped up back to 70 km/h within 9 s. When the lead car slowed down, participants had to release the throttle control—and most times also to apply the brake—in order to avoid a collision. Each driving trip was 25.7 km long, took about 25 min, and included ten instances where the lead car slowed down. Participants were instructed to drive as they normally would, to stay in the center of their lane, to keep their normal distance to the lead car. They were told not to pass the lead car and were informed that no car will pass them.

Street-crossing scenario

Participants walked on a non-motorized treadmill (Christopheit Magnetic Pro®), which allowed them to speed up, slow down, or stop whenever they deemed it appropriate. Treadmill position was registered optoelectronically and was used to control a visual display rendered by a modified version of the Carnetsoft® driving simulator. The display appeared again on three 46” TV screens covering a 195° horizontal field of view. This time, however, it showed a back alley, interrupted in regular intervals by streets with sidewalks on both sides (see Fig. 1b). Each street consisted of one 0.78 m wide lane in each direction. Cars travelled in both lanes at a constant speed of 50 km/h. To evaluate the influence of traffic flow, street crossing was tested with constant and with variable inter-vehicle distances: In group Constant (C), gaps between successive cars were always 5 s, while in group Variable (V), they followed the order 2.0, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0, 5.5, 6.0 s on each crossing trial. Cars in the distal lane reached the display center 1 s later than those in the proximal lane.

Each trial started in the back alley. Participants walked 15 m to the curb, watched the traffic, and crossed the street when they deemed it to be safe. Once they were on the opposite curb, they entered another back alley and thus started the next trial, for a total of 50 street-crossing trials. A trial was aborted when participants did not reach the opposite curb within 80 s, or when they collided with a vehicle. It took about 20 min to complete all 50 trials. Participants were instructed to walk as they normally would, to hold the treadmill’s handrail with their non-dominant hand for safety reasons, to keep a gap in traffic as they normally would, and not to stop at the medial since the cars in the distal lane will not stop for them.

Loading tasks

Car driving and street crossing were combined with loading tasks modeled after natural activities. Participants were instructed to give equal priority to the loading tasks and to the car-driving, respectively, street-crossing tasks. As in real life, those tasks differed with respect to stimulus modality (visual inputs on the central TV screen, auditory inputs over headphones), cognitive load (baseline, memory, reasoning), and/or output channel (verbal responses, manual typing). The following tasks were implemented in the driving scenario.

  • Typing-visual: A three-digit number was displayed for 8 s on the screen. Participants responded by typing that number into a keypad located at a convenient distance on their dominant (right or left) body side. This task simulated operating a radio receiver or GPS navigator.

  • Typing-auditory: Same, except that the number was spoken within about 1.8 s over headphones.

  • Reasoning-visual: A question that cannot be answered by ‘yes’ or ‘no’ was displayed for 5 s on the screen. Example: ‘what is the advantage of holding elections via the internet?’ Participants responded by talking into a microphone. This task simulated conversation with a car passenger or via hands-free mobile phones.

  • Reasoning-auditory: Same, except that the question was spoken within about 3.8 s over headphones

  • Memory-visual: As participants saw a gas station, they were asked over headphones whether the price displayed for super gas is the same as at the preceding gas station. Participants responded verbally.

  • Memory-auditory: After the participants heard a traffic announcement over headphones, they were asked whether the reported congestion (highway number, location, length) is the same as in the preceding traffic announcement.

The following tasks were implemented in the street-crossing scenario.

  • Typing-visual: Same as above, except that numbers were displayed, for 4 s each, on a billboard across the virtual street.

  • Typing-auditory: Same as above, except that the numbers were spoken within about 1.7 s each.

  • Memory-visual: Words denoting grocery products were sequentially displayed, for 3.5 s each, on a billboard across the street. Participants said ‘yes’ when the current product has been displayed earlier in the same crossing trial. This task simulated real-life recurrences such as rehearsing a shopping list while walking to a grocery store.

  • Memory-auditory: Same, except that products were presented over headphones for 0.7 s each.

Note that persons who engage in the car-driving or street-crossing scenarios and concurrently perform the loading tasks face many different stimuli, produce many different responses, and carry our meaningful activities presented in an ever-changing sequence. Both paradigms therefore satisfy the requirements for ecologically valid multitasking as proposed in Introduction section. In particular, both paradigms mimic the interplay of task switching and multitasking typically encountered in everyday life.

Procedures

In the driving scenario, each participant drove once without loading tasks (single-task driving) and once concurrently with the loading tasks (multitask driving). In the latter case, each loading task was presented ten times in a mixed sequence, i.e., participants could not anticipate which type of task would come next. The tasks were presented at specific locations along the road, separated by about 300 m (± 9 m) from each other as well as from instances where the lead car slowed down. Thus, loading tasks never coincided with the need to slow down for the lead car.

In addition to single- and multitask driving, each participant also completed a control condition in which the virtual world moved by in autopilot mode (to ensure a comparable visual stimulation) while the six loading tasks were presented in the same order as in multitask driving.

In the street-crossing scenario, each participant from group C and group V crossed the street ten times without a loading task (single-task crossing) and ten times with each of the four loading tasks (multitask crossing). In the latter case, a given loading task was presented repeatedly without breaks, from trial onset to trial end, to ensure that crossing and the loading task could not be dealt with sequentially. The tasks were presented in a mixed sequence, i.e., participants could not anticipate which task—if any—they would encounter on the next crossing. Each participant also completed a control condition in which the virtual world moved by in autopilot mode while the four loading tasks were presented in the same order as in multitask crossing.

Data registration

The car-driving and street-crossing scenarios registered a range of parameters, such as steering wheel angle and walking speed, all with a sampling rate of 10 Hz. For the purposes of the present feasibility study, we selected the following parameters as measures of driving performance.

  • Lateral position of participant’s car; a value of 0 m indicates that the car is centered in its lane, and a value of < − 0.78 m indicates that the car veers off the road.

  • SDLP: standard deviation of the lateral position

  • Distance to lead car; a value of 0 m indicates that the front bumper of the participant’s car touches the rear bumper of the lead car.

  • SDDLC: standard deviation of the distance to lead car.

SDLP and SDDLC are common performance measures in driving research. Since slowing down for the lead car never coincided with the presentation of a loading task (see above), low scores on SDLP and SDDLC always represent good performance.

In multitask driving, the above parameters were calculated during an interval that started with the presentation of a loading task and ended 1 s before the onset of the next loading task; the length of this interval was 15.5 ± 0.6 s. We decided to use this relatively long interval since a first view at our raw data revealed that loading tasks often had prolonged effects on driving. In single-task driving, the above parameters were calculated during same-length intervals in the same road segments, to equate for driving difficulty. Parameter values were averaged across the ten repetitions of each task. The following parameters were selected as measures of street-crossing performance on each trial.

  • Approach to curb: time interval from trial onset to the onset of walking across the proximal driving lane

  • Crossing gap: time interval between cars (rear bumper to front bumper) selected to cross the street. This parameter was constant at 5 s in group C.

  • Safety margin: metric distance between crossing participant and front bumper of nearest car when the participant is in the middle of the lane

  • Collision: occurrence (score 1) or non-occurrence (score 0) of a virtual collision between participant and oncoming car. Cars did not break for participants.

The above parameters were calculated once for each crossing trial and were subsequently averaged across the ten repetitions of each task.

Statistical methods

Driving parameters (lateral position, distance to lead car) and street-crossing parameters (approach to curb, crossing gap, safety margin) registered in this feasibility study were tested for reliability across all ten repetitions of each loading task by calculating Cronbach’s alpha scores. Parameters were tested for sensitivity to multitasking by submitting their across-repetition means to analyses of variance (ANOVAs). As the only exception, means of the parameter ‘collision’ were submitted to nonparametric tests since their distribution was conspicuously non-normal (61% of the registered data had the value ‘zero’).

For driving parameters, ANOVAs used the within-factors Loading Task and Condition. Since the parameters for single- and multitask driving were calculated from the same road segments (see above), a significant effect of Loading Task would indicate that some loading tasks or road segments were more difficult than others. A significant effect of Condition would indicate that driving performance was not the same under single- and under multitask conditions. A significant effect of Condition * Loading Task would indicate that the difference between single- and multitask conditions was not the same with all loading tasks.

For street-crossing parameters, ANOVAs used the within-factor Task (levels: single, typing-visual, typing-auditory, memory-visual, memory-auditory) and the between-factor Group (C, V). A significant effect of Task would indicate that performance was not the same with all tasks, for example, that it differed between the single-task condition and one or several of the multitask conditions.

Results

Driving

Table 1 summarizes the Cronbach’s alpha scores for the two driving parameters ‘lateral position’ and ‘distance to lead car,’ separately for single- and multitask conditions and for each loading task. The scores ranged between 0.87 and 0.95, indicating acceptable to high values (Bland and Altman 1997).

Figure 2a–d illustrates the across-participant means of all driving parameters, again separately for single- and multitask conditions and for each loading task. The graphs suggest that in the multitask condition, all loading tasks led to more lateral and less variable lane positions, as well as to larger and more variable lead car distances. Table 2 summarizes the pertinent ANOVA outcomes, which confirmed a significant difference between single- and multitask driving for the parameters ‘lateral position’ and SDDLC, but not for ‘distance to lead car’ and SDLP. Table 2 further reveals significant effects of Task, indicating that some road segments or loading tasks were more difficult to master than others (see above reasoning). Effect sizes were high for the significant effects of Condition and medium to high for those of Loading Task.

Street crossing

Table 3 summarizes the Cronbach’s alpha scores for street-crossing parameters, separately for each task. The scores ranged between 0.92 and 0.99, which again are high values.

Figure 3a–d illustrates the across-participant means of all street-crossing parameters, separately for each group and task. Group V took longer before departing from the curb, did so at shorter inter-vehicle intervals and with a smaller safety margin; accordingly, the number of collisions was higher in that group. Differences between tasks are less prominent in the graphs for both groups. Table 4 summarizes the ANOVA outcomes, which substantiate the observed group differences for the parameters ‘inter-vehicle interval’ and ‘safety margin’ but not for ‘approach to curb.’ Table 4 further reveals a significant effect of Task and a significant effect of Group * Task on the parameter ‘approach to curb’: The approach took longer when a typing task was added, more so in group V. Finally, Table 4 lists a significant effect of task on the parameter ‘safety margin’: The margin decreased when a typing task was added. Effect sizes were high for the significant effects of Condition and medium to high for those of Task and of the interaction term.

The effect of Group on the parameter ‘collision’ was statistically significant in Mann–Whitney’s U test (U = 1.5; Z = − 2.19; p < 0.05) with group V experiencing more collisions. The effect of Task was not significant in Friedman’s ANOVA when both groups were combined [χ2 (N = 10, FG = 4) = 2.34; p > 0.05], when only group C was considered [χ2 (N = 5, FG = 4) = 2.40; p > 0.05] or when only group V was considered [χ2 (N = 5, FG = 4) = 5.29; p > 0.05].

Discussion

The purpose of the present feasibility study was to demonstrate the feasibility of two experimental multitasking paradigms which reflect the natural demands for multitasking more closely than common dual-task paradigms. To this end, we implemented two everyday-like scenarios in virtual reality and combined them with an ever-changing sequence of meaningful concurrent task; as in everyday life, those tasks involved different input modalities, different cognitive loads, and/or different output channels. Our multitasking paradigms therefore required a natural combination of dual tasking and task switching. This is in contrast to earlier research which dealt with dual tasking only or with task switching only. Our paradigms are therefore likely to tax the supervisory attention system (see Sect. 1) more strongly and naturally than traditional paradigms do.

Cronbach’s alpha scores confirmed that driving and street-crossing parameters are reliable across task repetitions, and ANOVA outcomes confirmed that they are sensitive to the effects of multitasking. This suggests that our paradigm can be used for further research with a similar number of trials and with similar response parameters. Specifically, we plan a study which compares participants’ performance in our realistic multitasking approach (i.e., dual tasking plus task switching) with the same persons’ performance when loading tasks are presented in a blocked rather than an intermixed order (i.e., dual tasking only). We also plan to compare participants’ performance when the loading tasks are presented, without driving or street crossing, once in a mixed order (i.e., task switching only) and once in a blocked order (i.e., neither task switching nor dual tasking). The outcome will allow us to determine whether the costs of combined task switching and dual tasking are higher, comparable, or lower than the sum of switching costs and dual-task costs.

The specific pattern of findings in our study is in general agreement with data from earlier studies on dual-task performance in realistic scenarios. When our participants drove under multitask conditions, they steered the car closer to the curb and kept their distance to the lead car less steady, just as the participants in earlier research on dual-task driving (Drews et al. 2009; Horry and Wickens 2006; Strayer et al. 2003). The former finding may represent a compensatory strategy to avoid collisions with oncoming traffic, and the latter may be a symptom of a suboptimal distribution of attention. Furthermore, when our participants crossed a street under multitask conditions, they took longer to approach the curb and accepted a smaller safety margin, as did the participants in earlier studies on dual-task street crossing (Banducci et al. 2016; Byington and Schwebel 2013; Chaddock et al. 2012). This finding might again reflect a suboptimal distribution of attention. The qualitative agreement between our paradigms and earlier work does not imply, however, that the magnitude of effects is comparable; additional research is needed to find out (see preceding paragraph).

It is interesting to note that in the street-crossing scenario, participants from group V crossed at shorter inter-vehicle intervals, with smaller safety margins and with a higher number of collisions than those from group C. In other words, inter-vehicle intervals of 5 s (group C) allow for relatively safe crossing but participants from group V did not wait for those intervals but rather accepted shorter and riskier gaps in traffic. Thus, participants opted for speed rather than safety when given a choice, a strategy which can often be observed outside the laboratory, in real pedestrian traffic. Virtual reality scenarios may therefore be can be useful as an instructive and entertaining tool to educate the general public about the hazards of street crossing. Further work should be undertaken to explore the influence of different traffic flow patterns on street-crossing behavior of different populations in more depth.

Summing up, the present feasibility study suggests that our paradigm for realistic multitasking is reliable and sensitive. Since our setup is reasonably compact and affordable, and since scenarios and tasks can easily be modified by relatively small changes in the script language, we believe that this feasibility study is of interest not only for basic science, but also for prevention and rehabilitation settings. For even more compactness, treadmill and TV screens could be replaced by a head-mounted display, which, however, would limit the virtual walking space and increase the risk of simulator sickness.

This research was supported by Grants within the Priority Program SPP 1772 from the German Research Foundation (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, DFG), Grants BO 649/22-1 and VO 1432/19-1. One of the authors (WvW) owns the Carnetsoft® company, which sells the driving simulator used in our study. Neither the person nor the company provided financial support for our work. We undertook every effort to avoid any reporting bias and any advertorial content.
